page.title: 17CHANGES IN NESSCLIFFE CONT
page.content: The toilets, buckets surrounded by wooden casing, were across the yard and emptied and disinfected once a week by the caretaker. The houses had no electricity. Paraffin lamps and candles were used for lighting. Where I lived no water was laid on, just a raintub and pump in the garden. You had to heat all your water on the fire or Primus stove for a bath once a week in a large galvanised bath, in front of the fire in winter and outside in the shed in summer. There were no drains to pour your water down, you had to dig a culvert and let it soak away. It was the same in most places.
